Award.AwardTitle: 2016 NSF CISE CAREER Proposal Writing Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant is the NSF's most prestigious award bestowed on outstanding tenure-track faculty members to support their exceptional research and educational activities. This proposal proposes to organize the 2016 NSF CISE CAREER Proposal Writing Workshop in Arlington, VA on April 4, 2016. It is expected that 200 junior faculty will attend this workshop, including a significant portion of attendees from HBCU/MEI and under-represented groups. At the early stage of their academic careers, many junior faculty have lacked grant-writing experience, which could lead to an unsatisfactory presentation of their research and education activities. To address this problem, this workshop will allow junior faculty to obtain first-hand experiences through the combination of a number of interactive activities with recent CISE CAREER awardees and NSF program directors.

The one-day workshop will consist of the presentations on CISE CAREER solicitation, talks given by recent CAREER awardees, mock panels, as well as program-specific discussions with NSF program managers. The opportunities to interact with NSF program managers will be valuable to junior faculty in developing competitive CAREER proposals.

The workshop is open to all CAREER-eligible principal investigators in NSF-supported disciplines at U.S. universities and colleges. Preferences will be given to junior faculty in CISE-related disciplines. About 200 junior faculty are expected to attend. A number of fellowships will be given to junior faculty from HBCU/MEI and under-represented groups, including women. This will provide necessary travel support for those faculty to attend the workshop. The presentations by recent CISE CAREER awardees will be podcasted online and the slides and videos will be available on the workshop website for other faculty who might not be able to attend the workshop in person. This will ensure the workshop to achieve a broader impact among junior faculty within the CISE community.

By attending the workshop, junior faculty will have a better understanding of the NSF CAREER program and obtain valuable insights from the CAREER awardees and NSF program managers. The mock panel and program-specific breakout sessions will also provide constructive feedback to junior faculty. This workshop will help prepare junior faculty in CISE-related disciplines to develop outstanding research and education activities at their universities and write competitive CAREER proposals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF CISE Career Proposal Writing Workshop 2016 was organized in Westin Hotel, Arlington, VA on April 4, 2016. The workshop was hosted by The George Washington University. The purpose of the workshop was to engage the junior faculty (at the assistant professor level) in the CISE-related disciplines from across the US, and provide them with useful information on how to improve their success in winning the prestigious NSF Faculty Early Career Award, the flagship program that has provided a much needed starting point for several new junior faculty with promising new research ideas.

 

The workshop organizers setup a webpage to solicit applications from assistant professors in CISE disciplines, and workshop was advertised through several mailing lists.  A total of 297 applications were received, and every effort was made to accommodate the first-time workshop attendees, with travel support offered to faculty from underrepresented groups (female and HBCU/HSI institution).  A total of 214 applicants were selected to attend the workshop, with 45 attendees from the underrepresented group. The workshop had a keynote talk delivered by the CISE division director, along with a Q&A panel with program directors from each of the four CISE divisions. The workshop also included four talks by prior NSF CISE Career awardees with an interactive discussion session to share their experience with NSF Career proposal submission process. The George Washington University organized breakout sessions in the nearby GWU Arlington Campus, where the attendees were able to interact with CISE program directors on more specific research topics within the division.

 

As part of the registration, each attendee was asked to submit a 2-3 page draft proposal summarizing their ideas for a potential NSF career proposal submission. This information was used to identify the potential CISE division that may be suitable for their research interest. Each attendee was offered an option of having a 15-minute meeting a program director on April 5, 2016, for which 210 attendees showed positive interest. All of these 210 attendees were given a pre-arranged 15-minute meeting with a NSF program director who closely matched the participant’s research interest. For the participants, it provided a face-to-face meeting opportunity with NSF program directors, and a chance to hear direct feedback from them on how to best present their research ideas in their NSF career proposals.

 

At the end of the workshop, an online feedback survey was conducted. 85% of the workshop participants indicated that they learned a lot of new information from attending the workshop, and 95% of the participants indicated that they found the face-to-face meeting with the CISE program directors to be extremely valuable.

 

The PI actively communicated with the workshop attendees through a specially created mailing list, and coordinated with the NSF program directors at every step to ensure the success of the workshop.  3 graduate students helped the PI with the registration and reception of attendees and floor logistics during the workshop event.

 

Overall, the workshop served to significantly improve the understanding of NSF CISE Faculty Early Career program among junior faculty from across the US, as evidenced by our post-workshop survey results. Travel support was provided to under-represented groups such as female faculty participants and faculty from HBCU/HSI institutions. 21% of the workshop attendees took advantage of this travel support that helped them to cover their lodging and travel expenses.
